p.sent: The biggest shortfall in the free software world today is not in the software---it is the lack of good free documentation that we can include with the free software.
Many of the most important programs do not come with free reference manuals and free introductory texts.
Documentation is an essential part of any software package; when an important free software package does not come with a free manual and a free tutorial, that is a major gap.
We have many such gaps today.
How did these gaps arise?
Most often because the developers of free software do not recognize the need for free documentation.

Many times we have heard a free software user eagerly describe a manual that he is writing, intended as a contribution to the community, only to learn that he had ruined it entirely by signing a publication contract to make it non-free.
Free documentation, like free software, is a matter of freedom, not price.
The problem with the non-free manual is not that publishers charge a price for printed copies---that in itself is fine.
The problem is the restrictions on the use of the manual.
